Prevent errors whenever possible
No one likes the feeling of filling out an entire form and getting an error after
submitting it, so your form design must account for preventing errors. This can be
accomplished in different ways:
Use helper text to provide specific instructions about a form field
e If a field needs further explanation on how to be filled out, make use of helper text.
e If helper text isn't going to be enough, consider redesigning the form, for example by splitting
up the information into smaller and simpler nuggets.
Use real-time field validation whenever possible
e When an input field gets focused out (after being focused on) it should be validated. If it's
expecting a numeric entry and it has a string or if it's a required one and it was left blank, always
show the component error message. Don't leave all validations until after the submit button is
pressed. If you can prevent an error on submit, do it.
¢ Only display the success state of a component if it has previously been in an error state, and has
been corrected.
e For form validation, make sure to scroll the page to the first error on the form and mark all other
ones that have errors.
e Keep the submit button always enabled because hitting it will force the form validation and can
show new errors. Always accept only the first click, as users with motor disabilities might click
the button several times unintentionally.
e Ifa form has an error after submission, the title of the page should get prefixed with “Error:”, for
example, “Error: Join IKEA Family”, to better cater to screen reader users.

Provide useful, friendly error messages
When writing any error messages, consider our voice and tone —the friendly IKEA
coworker. This is our close-to-home personification of each of our nine personality
traits. They’re someone who knows that the customer wants correct information,
guidance and can lead them to the right place if they need additional help.
An error code can be easy for communicating with customer support but it must be
accompanied by a comprehensive error message. Users should be able to understand
what happened and if there's something they can do to fix or prevent it from happening
again.
Error handling for checkboxes and radio buttons
One error message at the end of the group communicates the error state for the entire
group. See more under the corresponding component documentation for the Checkbox
and Radio Button.
Inform which fields are optional
Since we aim to ask the minimum amount of information, by default all fields are
treated as required. If a field is not essential, and it needs to be displayed, it should be
labeled accordingly by having ‘(optional)' added to the end of the label.

Arranging components
Group related information
Consider forms as a conversation between you and the user. It's easier for users to
understand related information when they're grouped together on blocks or fieldsets.
Order forms logically
Just as important as grouping related info together, the order of the fields should feel
intuitive and logical for the user. You will probably never ask for an address ahead of
name, for example.

Avoid multiple columns
e If possible, stick to single-column forms. Besides being mobile-friendly from the start, it prevents
users from reading in a different order as intended and misinterpreting the form.
e If creating multiple columns is needed, make sure users can navigate the form in a logical way
using the Tab key.
Space between components
Component spacing is very important to enable users to easily scan information and
can also be used to create a sense of a set. It should always be adjusted as a whole, not
individually.
When thinking about component states, be mindful about extra information that can be
displayed, such as error messages. Use enough space to make it clear that the error
message or the help message is attached to the field above, not the one beneath it.
